awd_titl_txt: Multiaxial Distortional-Hardening Plasticity to Advance Forming Process Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Sheet metal forming processes are among the most flexible and energy-efficient manufacturing processes, corresponding to approximately 7 percent of the US Gross Domestic Product. Transformation of the sheet into a useful component typically occurs in multiple steps, with the part transferred from one forming die to the next, progressively obtaining a more complex shape. While these multi-step processes enable the creation of complex components, they also increase the cost due to the number of dies and presses needed. Also, from a scientific point of view, the multiple steps cause repeated loading and unloading of the materials, which is very challenging to model in a computationally-efficient way. This research aims to create a material model suitable for repeated loading and unloading, to enable science-based process and die design, minimize the number of necessary steps, reduce waste and thus enhance the competitiveness of American manufacturing. Since the automotive industry is one of the major users of multi-step sheet forming, this research will also enable the use of modern, difficult-to-form steels and aluminum alloys in auto-bodies, yielding safer and environmentally friendlier cars. The work will be performed in collaboration with 2 Korean universities (whose work is funded by the Korean National Research Foundation), and this collaboration will allow access to equipment and expertise not otherwise available in the US. Graduate and undergraduate students and Research Experience for Teachers (RET) participants and their students will benefit from the industrial focus of this project, as well as its international dimension.

To provide industry with a robust and computationally-efficient material model suitable for severe strain-path changes, including repeated loading and unloading, this research will: 1) create a unique machine for biaxial tension/compression of sheets and perform multiaxial plasticity experiments, 2) use this dataset to evolve the recent (2011) Homogeneous Anisotropic Hardening (HAH) plasticity model and create the extended-HAH one, to capture the experiments, and 3) conduct multi-step forming experiments and simulate them with the extended-HAH model, to further inform its evolution and validate its performance. Two families of materials, advanced high strength steels and aluminum alloys, will be investigated in this research, both of which are of interest to various weight-sensitive applications, but have widely varying responses to severe strain-path changes. Beyond the specific forming processes studied here, the creation of a robust and computationally-efficient material model to describe severe strain-path changes is expected to benefit the modeling of all multi-step plastic deformation processes in industry, as well as low-cycle fatigue and cyclic plasticity.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Most of the sheet and tube components around us are produced with multi-step forming processes, where they are transferred from one forming die to the next, progressively obtaining a more intricate shape. While this enables the creation of complex components, it also increases the cost due to the number of dies and presses needed. Science-based process- and die-design using Finite Element Analysis (FEA) can rationalize the number of necessary steps, minimize trial-and-error and waste and thus enable a more efficient production. It can also enable the broader use of newer materials (Advanced High-Strength Steels/AHSS and Aluminum alloys) in the transportation industry, yielding safer and environmentally friendlier cars. But successful FEA predictions require efficient, reliable and robust plasticity models, that can represent accurately the severe strain-path changes during multi-step forming.

The main research objectives of this award were to: 1) create a plasticity model that can accurately predict the behavior of metallic sheets under severe strain-path changes; 2) use this model to predict behavior during plastic forming and formability after severe strain-path changes; 3) use the plasticity and formability models in simulating actual multi-step sheet and tube forming manufacturing processes, and compare with forming experiments. These objectives were met by identifying an advanced material model for distortional hardening (HAH-20) and comparing its performance with more traditional, combined isotropic-kinematic hardening. For the identification, a dedicated testing machine for continuous tension-compression of thin sheets was custom-designed and manufactured. Furthermore, for multiaxial loading, a cruciform-like specimen for combined tension and shear of thin sheets was created, generating unique data for AHSS. Unique benchmark experiments on plasticity under severe strain-path changes were performed by inflating SS-304L microtubes. The performance of the plasticity models was examined with the novel use of the hole-expansion experiment, using both as-received and prestrained sheets, and with the aid of Digital Image Correlation (DIC). Beyond the specific forming processes studied here, the creation of a robust and computationally efficient material model to describe severe strain-path changes is expected to benefit the modeling of all multi-step plastic deformation processes in industry, as well as low-cycle fatigue and cyclic plasticity.

This project is a US-Korea collaboration in Advanced Manufacturing. Therefore, it has included both US (Ohio State Univ., Univ. New Hampshire) and Korean (POSTECH, Seoul Nat. Univ.) institutions. Furthermore, it has involved the Tokyo Univ. of Agric. & Technology (Japan) and the Univ. Bundeswehr (Germany). These collaborations were reinforced by personnel exchanges, and joint publications. Notably, of the 8 students and post-docs who worked on the project, 5 are female.


Last Modified: 01/02/2024
Modified by: Ioannis Korkolis
